articles.headline: Can a Brash Executive in Kansas Save Movie Theaters?
articles.snippet: For Adam Aron, who runs AMC Entertainment, the world’s largest movie theater chain, the past year has been filled with twists and turns. And no one knows the ending.
articles.abstract: For Adam Aron, who runs AMC Entertainment, the world’s largest movie theater chain, the past year has been filled with twists and turns. And no one knows the ending.
articles.lead_paragraph: Most of the time, the 116-year-old movie theater business is rather humdrum.

articles.headline: A Year Later, the First Post-Pandemic City
articles.snippet: A year ago, Wuhan offered a warning about the coronavirus. Now, it heralds a world where relief at the recovery  conceals the emotional aftershocks.
articles.abstract: A year ago, Wuhan offered a warning about the coronavirus. Now, it heralds a world where relief at the recovery  conceals the emotional aftershocks.
articles.lead_paragraph: The long months of harsh lockdown have faded from view in Wuhan, the first city in the world devastated by the new coronavirus. As residents look to move on, they cite a Chinese saying that warns against “forgetting the pain after a scar heals.”
articles.byline: By Gilles Sabrié, Chris Buckley, Keith Bradsher, Vivian Wang and Amy Qin

articles.headline: Trump and Justice Dept. Lawyer Said to Have Plotted to Oust Acting Attorney General
articles.snippet: Trying to find another avenue to push his baseless election claims, Donald Trump considered installing a loyalist.
articles.abstract: Trying to find another avenue to push his baseless election claims, Donald Trump considered installing a loyalist.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department’s top leaders listened in stunned silence this month: One of their peers, they were told, had devised a plan with President Donald J. Trump to oust Jeffrey A. Rosen as acting attorney general and wield the department’s power to force Georgia state lawmakers to overturn its presidential election results.

articles.headline: Senate Leaders Agree on Impeachment Trial Delay, Giving Biden Breathing Room
articles.snippet: The plan would put off the historic proceeding until Feb. 9, giving former President Donald J. Trump time to prepare his defense and allowing President Biden to fill his cabinet and begin work on his agenda.
articles.abstract: The plan would put off the historic proceeding until Feb. 9, giving former President Donald J. Trump time to prepare his defense and allowing President Biden to fill his cabinet and begin work on his agenda.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senate leaders struck a deal on Friday to delay former President Donald J. Trump’s impeachment trial for two weeks, giving President Biden time to install his cabinet and begin moving a legislative agenda before they begin a historic proceeding to try his predecessor.

articles.headline: Trump’s Last-Minute Pardon Frees Man Still Facing Accusations of Violence
articles.snippet: Jonathan Braun’s 10-year sentence for running a drug ring was commuted by the departing president. The White House did not mention that he faces separate accusations of violence and threats.
articles.abstract: Jonathan Braun’s 10-year sentence for running a drug ring was commuted by the departing president. The White House did not mention that he faces separate accusations of violence and threats.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Donald J. Trump’s late-night commutation of a 10-year prison sentence being served by a drug smuggler named Jonathan Braun made the action sound almost routine. The White House said only that upon his release, Mr. Braun would “seek employment to support his wife and children.”
articles.byline: By Michael S. Schmidt, Maggie Haberman and William K. Rashbaum

articles.headline: How Alvin the Beagle Helped Usher In a Democratic Senate
articles.snippet: Senator Raphael Warnock was sworn in this week as Georgia’s first Black senator, and he arrived with a canny canine assist.
articles.abstract: Senator Raphael Warnock was sworn in this week as Georgia’s first Black senator, and he arrived with a canny canine assist.
articles.lead_paragraph: The dog had a lot of work to do.

articles.headline: If Poor Countries Go Unvaccinated, a Study Says, Rich Ones Will Pay
articles.snippet: A failure to distribute the Covid-19 vaccine in poor nations will worsen economic damage, with half the costs borne by wealthy countries, new research shows.
articles.abstract: A failure to distribute the Covid-19 vaccine in poor nations will worsen economic damage, with half the costs borne by wealthy countries, new research shows.
articles.lead_paragraph: In monopolizing the supply of vaccines against Covid-19, wealthy nations are threatening more than a humanitarian catastrophe: The resulting economic devastation will hit affluent countries nearly as hard as those in the developing world.

articles.headline: High School Grades Could Be Worth $100,000. Time to Tell Your Child?
articles.snippet: Most colleges and universities now use a “merit” aid strategy to solicit teenagers. Your eighth grader probably ought to know how it works.
articles.abstract: Most colleges and universities now use a “merit” aid strategy to solicit teenagers. Your eighth grader probably ought to know how it works.
articles.lead_paragraph: Financial aid is no longer just about what you earn and what you have. It’s also about your children and what they do — and that means that good grades can be worth a whole lot of money.

articles.headline: Barred From U.S. Under Trump, Muslims Exult in Biden’s Open Door
articles.snippet: Few foreigners welcomed President Biden’s election victory as enthusiastically as the tens of thousands of Muslims who have been locked out of the United States for the past four years.
articles.abstract: Few foreigners welcomed President Biden’s election victory as enthusiastically as the tens of thousands of Muslims who have been locked out of the United States for the past four years.
articles.lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — As the results of the American presidential election rolled in on Nov. 4, a young Sudanese couple sat up through the night in their small town south of Khartoum, eyes glued to the television as state tallies were declared, watching anxiously. They had a lot riding on the outcome.

articles.headline: Biden Seeks to Define His Presidency by an Early Emphasis on Equity
articles.snippet: Only two presidents before him have used their first weeks in office to push for equality with the same force, according to one historian.
articles.abstract: Only two presidents before him have used their first weeks in office to push for equality with the same force, according to one historian.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In his first days in office, President Biden has devoted more attention to issues of racial equity than any new president since Lyndon B. Johnson, a focus that has cheered civil rights activists and drawn early criticism from conservatives.
articles.byline: By Jim Tankersley and Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: ‘We Are Forced to Live in These Conditions’: In Los Angeles, Virus Ravages Overcrowded Homes
articles.snippet: Perhaps nowhere else in America can the unequal toll of the virus be felt more dramatically. Suburban sprawl and freeways demarcate the neighborhoods of the haves and the have-nots.
articles.abstract: Perhaps nowhere else in America can the unequal toll of the virus be felt more dramatically. Suburban sprawl and freeways demarcate the neighborhoods of the haves and the have-nots.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Betty Rivera was the first in her household to fall sick, early last month. To protect her family, she locked herself in the bedroom she shares with her grandson. Her daughter left chicken soup and herbal remedies of ginger and garlic and rosemary outside her door.

articles.headline: Inside the Deadly Capitol Shooting
articles.snippet: With a mob approaching, a police lieutenant fatally shot a woman trying to vault through a window near the House Chamber.
articles.abstract: With a mob approaching, a police lieutenant fatally shot a woman trying to vault through a window near the House Chamber.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — During the four-and-a-half-hour attack on the Capitol on Jan. 6, one of the moments when the mob came closest to the lawmakers they were pursuing took place just after 2:30 p.m.
articles.byline: By Adam Goldman and Shaila Dewan

articles.headline: Pennsylvania Lawmaker Played Key Role in Trump’s Plot to Oust Acting Attorney General
articles.snippet: The congressman’s involvement underlined how far the former president was willing to go to overturn the election, and Democratic lawmakers have begun calling for investigations into those efforts.
articles.abstract: The congressman’s involvement underlined how far the former president was willing to go to overturn the election, and Democratic lawmakers have begun calling for investigations into those efforts.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Representative Scott Perry joined his colleagues in a monthslong campaign to undermine the results of the presidential election, promoting “Stop the Steal” events and supporting an attempt to overturn millions of legally cast votes, he often took a back seat to higher-profile loyalists in President Donald J. Trump’s orbit.
articles.byline: By Katie Benner and Catie Edmondson

articles.headline: Surge of Student Suicides Pushes Las Vegas Schools to Reopen
articles.snippet: Firmly linking teen suicides to school closings is difficult, but rising mental health emergencies and suicide rates point to the toll the pandemic lockdown is taking.
articles.abstract: Firmly linking teen suicides to school closings is difficult, but rising mental health emergencies and suicide rates point to the toll the pandemic lockdown is taking.
articles.lead_paragraph: The reminders of pandemic-driven suffering among students in Clark County, Nev., have come in droves.

articles.headline: How Democrats Planned for Doomsday
articles.snippet: A huge coalition of activist groups had been working together since the spring to make sure that Joe Biden won and that the “election stayed won” amid Donald Trump’s subterfuge.
articles.abstract: A huge coalition of activist groups had been working together since the spring to make sure that Joe Biden won and that the “election stayed won” amid Donald Trump’s subterfuge.
articles.lead_paragraph: The video call was announced on short notice, but more than 900 people quickly joined: a coalition of union officials and racial justice organizers, civil rights lawyers and campaign strategists, pulled together in a matter of hours after the Jan. 6 attack on Capitol Hill.

articles.headline: Capitol Riot Puts Spotlight on ‘Apocalyptically Minded’ Global Far Right
articles.snippet: Leaderless but united by racist ideology that has been supercharged by social media, extremists have built a web of real and online connections that worries officials.
articles.abstract: Leaderless but united by racist ideology that has been supercharged by social media, extremists have built a web of real and online connections that worries officials.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN — When insurrectionists stormed the Capitol in Washington this month, far-right extremists across the Atlantic cheered. Jürgen Elsässer, the editor of Germany’s most prominent far-right magazine, was watching live from his couch.
articles.byline: By Katrin Bennhold and Michael Schwirtz

articles.headline: How to Keep Internet Trolls Out of Remote Workplaces
articles.snippet: When companies move all employee communications online, they face the same problems as the rest of the internet. But they don’t have to let bad behavior seep in.
articles.abstract: When companies move all employee communications online, they face the same problems as the rest of the internet. But they don’t have to let bad behavior seep in.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publishers like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

articles.headline: How West Virginia Became a U.S. Leader in Vaccine Rollout
articles.snippet: West Virginia has used 83 percent of its allotted vaccines, among the best in the nation. But even efficient operations face a major problem: There simply are not enough shots to go around.
articles.abstract: West Virginia has used 83 percent of its allotted vaccines, among the best in the nation. But even efficient operations face a major problem: There simply are not enough shots to go around.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, W.Va. — Carolyn Zain had heard horror stories about the nation’s coronavirus vaccine rollout: long waits, clunky websites, people being turned away. So when her health department announced it was expanding appointments, she armed herself with two phones — cellphone in one hand, landline in the other — and held her breath.

articles.headline: How Space Became the Next ‘Great Power’ Contest Between the U.S. and China
articles.snippet: The Biden administration faces not only waves of Chinese antisatellite weapons but a history of jumbled responses to the intensifying threat.
articles.abstract: The Biden administration faces not only waves of Chinese antisatellite weapons but a history of jumbled responses to the intensifying threat.
articles.lead_paragraph: Beijing’s rush for antisatellite arms began 15 years ago. Now, it can threaten the orbital fleets that give the United States military its technological edge. Advanced weapons at China’s military bases can fire warheads that smash satellites and can shoot laser beams that have a potential to blind arrays of delicate sensors.

articles.headline: Trump Wants Back on Facebook. This Star-Studded Jury Might Let Him.
articles.snippet: A new kind of corporate supercourt is looking for legitimacy.
articles.abstract: A new kind of corporate supercourt is looking for legitimacy.
articles.lead_paragraph: They meet mostly on Zoom, but I prefer to picture the members of this court, or council, or whatever it is, wearing reflective suits and hovering via hologram around a glowing table. The members include two people who were reportedly on presidential shortlists for the U.S. Supreme Court, along with a Yemeni Nobel Peace Prize laureate, a British Pulitzer winner, Colombia’s leading human rights lawyer and a former prime minister of Denmark. The 20 of them come, in all, from 18 countries on six continents, and speak 27 languages among them.

articles.headline: Jeffrey Clark Was Considered Unassuming. Then He Plotted With Trump.
articles.snippet: Justice Department colleagues said they were shocked by Mr. Clark’s embrace of the president’s falsehoods and plan to oust the acting attorney general in an effort to overturn Georgia’s election results.
articles.abstract: Justice Department colleagues said they were shocked by Mr. Clark’s embrace of the president’s falsehoods and plan to oust the acting attorney general in an effort to overturn Georgia’s election results.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It was New Year’s Eve, but the Justice Department’s top leaders had little to celebrate as they discussed Jeffrey Clark, the acting head of the civil division, who had repeatedly pushed them to help President Donald J. Trump undo his electoral loss.
articles.byline: By Katie Benner and Charlie Savage

articles.headline: Europe’s Bankruptcies Are Plummeting. That May Be a Problem.
articles.snippet: Governments have extended national programs to keep troubled businesses afloat, but the aid may only be postponing a painful reckoning.
articles.abstract: Governments have extended national programs to keep troubled businesses afloat, but the aid may only be postponing a painful reckoning.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — Romain Rozier’s cafe should be bankrupt by now.

articles.headline: China Wanted to Show Off Its Vaccines. It’s Backfiring.
articles.snippet: Delays, inconsistent data, spotty disclosures and the country’s attacks on Western rivals have marred its ambitious effort to portray itself as a leader in global health.
articles.abstract: Delays, inconsistent data, spotty disclosures and the country’s attacks on Western rivals have marred its ambitious effort to portray itself as a leader in global health.
articles.lead_paragraph: China’s coronavirus vaccines were supposed to deliver a geopolitical win that showcased the country’s scientific prowess and generosity. Instead, in some places, they have set off a backlash.

articles.headline: How Options Trading Could Be Fueling a Stock Market Bubble
articles.snippet: A swell of individual investors are betting that stocks will go up. That enthusiasm is having a growing influence over the regular stock market itself.
articles.abstract: A swell of individual investors are betting that stocks will go up. That enthusiasm is having a growing influence over the regular stock market itself.
articles.lead_paragraph: The stock market is near record highs, and optimism abounds. Coronavirus vaccines are finally being jabbed into arms. Interest rates are at historic lows. And the Democrats who control Washington are expected to pour another trillion dollars or so into the still-struggling economy.

articles.headline: Amazon Union Drive Takes Hold in Unlikely Place
articles.snippet: Workers at a warehouse in Bessemer, Ala., are to vote next month on whether to unionize, the largest and most viable effort of its kind involving the technology giant.
articles.abstract: Workers at a warehouse in Bessemer, Ala., are to vote next month on whether to unionize, the largest and most viable effort of its kind involving the technology giant.
articles.lead_paragraph: The largest, most viable effort to unionize Amazon in many years began last summer not in a union stronghold like New York or Michigan, but at a Fairfield Inn outside Birmingham, in the right-to-work state of Alabama.
articles.byline: By Michael Corkery and Karen Weise
